importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's update, indicating when the developments involving Curtis Sliwa, John Catsimatidis, and Andrew Cuomo in the NYC mayoral race were reported.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period during which key developments occurred, including Catsimatidis urging Sliwa to drop out, Sliwa’s rebuttal on YouTube, and Trump’s dismissal of Sliwa.

keyTakeAways: Curtis Sliwa, a Republican mayoral candidate in New York City, is under pressure to drop out of the race from his boss, John Catsimatidis.
John Catsimatidis, a Republican supermarket magnate and longtime New Yorker, publicly urged Sliwa to exit the race on WABC-AM, citing a need for Sliwa to love New York more than anything else.
Andrew Cuomo, running as an independent, is rallying Republican support to oppose Democratic nominee Zohran Mamdani, and has criticized Sliwa as not viable or alternative to Mamdani.
Sliwa has dismissed Cuomo and his backers, arguing that billionaire donors should not dictate the future of New York City and that he represents blue-collar working-class voters.
Trump has dismissed Sliwa, calling him 'not exactly primetime' and mocking his affinity for cats and animal rescues, showing lack of endorsement.
Sliwa, known for founding the Guardian Angels, has never held political office and is polling third in the mayoral race.
Mamdani and Sliwa are now seen as unexpected allies, with Mamdani rejecting claims of coordination and both emphasizing that New Yorkers should decide who governs, not billionaire donors.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Curtis Sliwa, a Republican mayoral candidate in New York City, is facing mounting pressure to withdraw from the race, including direct intervention from his boss John Catsimatidis, who urges him to step down in favor of a unified Republican opposition to the Democratic nominee Zohran Mamdani. Andrew Cuomo, running as an independent, is actively working to consolidate Republican support and discredit Sliwa as a viable alternative, calling him a 'shock jock' and claiming he's not a real alternative. Sliwa, known for founding the Guardian Angels and his grassroots appeal, has rejected the pressure, arguing that billionaire donors should not dictate city politics and that he represents working-class New Yorkers. Meanwhile, President Donald Trump has dismissed Sliwa, mocking his cat-related image and political style, while Mamdani and Sliwa are seen as unexpected allies, with both asserting that New Yorkers should decide who governs, not donors or political elites.
title: Curtis Sliwa’s boss becomes the latest Republican trying to push him out of NYC mayoral race
